Alice, tend to Delilah. For a long moment Alice just stands there glaring.

DAYLIGHT AND A BASIN OF BLOODY WATER and Little Sue is ju dipping another towel in the hot water next to Delilah's bed, changing the bandages. All the whores are there in various states of dress, lounging on the floor, leaning against the wall.

With what Kate got, Silky got some, an' mine, an' Little S...

The hog in the mud, snorting and squealing, ugly as hell BILL MUNNY in the mud with him, pushing and shoving, tryi to move the stubborn animal and Munny goes down face firs and comes up more covered with mud than he already was an the words on the screen say, WRITTEN WORDS (super) Some months later, Hodgeman County, Kansas. Munny is thirty-five or forty years old, his hair is thin and his moustache droops glumly over his stubbled jaw. If it were not for his eyes he would look like any pig farme with his canvas overalls tucked in his boots pushing on a hog. Well, Uncle Pete said you was the goddamndest meanest sonofabitch ever lived an' if I ever wanted a partner for a killin', you was the worst one. Meanin' the best. On account of you're cold as snow an' don't have no weak nerve nor fear. Munny serves the coffee gloomily and sits down. It appear his feelings are hurt but The Kid doesn't notices.

CLOSE on CLEAN CERAMIC COFFEE MUGS as NED takes them from tidy cabinet in his cozy kitchen with the cast iron stove the solid table. Munny is sitting at the table looking moodily into space.
(earnestly) We ain't bad men no more, Bill. Hell, we're farmers.
(thoughtfully) Should be easy killin' em... supposin' they don't run off to Texas first.
(taking the pot from the stove) How long since you shot a gun ata man? (pause) Nine... ten years?
Eleven.

Easy, huh? Hell, I don't know that it was all that easy then... an' we was young an' full of beans. (pouring coffee) Bill... if you was mad at ‘em... if they done you wrong... I could see shootin' 'em...  25.
(looking Ned in the eye) We done stuff before for money, Ned.
(sitting down) Well, we thought we was doin' it for money... (he pauses, remembering) What'd they do anyhow? Cheat at cards, steal some strays, spit ona rich fella?
Cut up a woman. Cut her eyes out, cut her tits off, cut her fingers off... done everythin' but cut up her cunny, I guess.

(after chewing on that one) Well, I guess they got it comin'... (and he pauses and looks Munny in the eye) But you wouldn't go if Claudia was alive. It hits Munny like salt in a wound and he just takes it. They both know Ned is right and they think about it silen Finally Munny speaks glumly.

(getting up and going to the door) I guess you wouldn't mind to look in on my youngsters next week. Might be you could help them move a couple of them pigs i they got to separate 'em more. Ned has been thinking about it while Munny's talking, wrestling with it and now Munny is out the door.
How long you gonna be, Bill?
Two weeks, I guess.
This Kid, what's he like?  26. Munny turns and looks at Ned and their eyes meet and Munn realizes Ned is coming.
Three ways?
Yup. You still got the Spencer rifle?
(grinning) Yeah, an' I could still hit a bird in the eye flyin'.
Munny landing with a thud in the dust and picking himself hurriedly and casting a sheepish glance over his shoulder Ned as he makes another awkward effort to mount the mare.
(amazed at this performance) Jesus, Bill.
The sad, wise eyes of Sally Two Trees as she watches the riders disappearing in the distance. her eyes are saying good-bye.
THE RIDERS IN THE DISTANCE. One horse is walking and the white one is prancing and shying in an unruly manner whil her rider fights desperately for control.
SUNSET, and Ned and Munny riding in open country.
He musta been movin' right along.
We'll come across him tomorra, I guess.

Night and the sizzling campfire as Ned empties the grease from the frying pan into the fire. Munny is already lying down, fussing in his blankets to g comfortable and the crickets are chirping up a storm.  27.
Got used to my bed. Ain't gonna feel to home out here.
(getting into his blankets) Well, it ain't just the bed I'm gonna miss. I'm... (he stops suddenly) Hell, Billy, I'm sorry. I didn't mean...
It ain't nothin', don't fret it. (pause) She don't like it much, you goin' off with me.
Sally?
She gave me the evil eye.
It's just... she's a Indian an' Indians ain't... overfriendly.

I ain't blamin' her, Ned, I ain't holdin' it against her. (pause) She knew me back then... an' she seen what a no good sonofabitch I was... an' she won't allow how I've changed. She just don't know how I ain't like that no more.
Well, she...

(urgently) I ain't the same, Ned. Claudia, she... straightened me up, got me clear of the whiskey an' all. Us goin' to do this killin'... that don't mean I'm back to like I was. I just need the money... for a new start... for them youngsters. (long pause) Remember that drover, the one I shot in the mouth so's the teeth come out the back of his head? (MORE )
(long pause) (CONT'D) I dream about him now an' again. I didn't have no reason to shoot him... not one I could remember when I sobered up.
You was a... a crazy sonofabitch.
Nobody liked me... none of the boys. They was scared of me... figured I might shoot 'em out of pure meanness.
You ain't like that no more.
Eagle... he hated my guts. Bonaparte didn't like me none.
Nor Quincy, I guess.
Quincy, he was always watchin' me. Scared.
You ain't like that no more.
Hell, no. I'm just a fella now. ain't no different from anyone else no more. After a pause, Ned rolls over to go to sleep and says something kind by way of saying goodnight.
Hell, Bill, I always liked you... even back then. Ned settles in his covers and so does Munny and the crick chirp for a long moment but Munny can't sleep with the li
No you didn't. You wasn't no different, Ned. (and we...)
DAYLIGHT and a train whistle SCREAMING.  29.

The headline on the newspaper says "President Garfield Wounded." FUZZY, a cowboy, is sitting in the rocking coac reading the paper with great effort, partly because of th motion of the train and partly because Fuzzy can't read v well... but CROCKER, the rough looking cowboy on the seat next to him can't read at all.

All I want to know is what sonofabitch shot him, that's all. Was it one of them John Bull assholes? Across the aisle two well dressed gentlemen are sitting. The one by the window, the lean one in the frock coat and slouch hat, is WW BEAUCHAMP and the one on the aisle, pud pinkcheeked, with neat muttonchop whiskers, wearing a fro coat and waistcoat and a silk slouch hat in spite of the heat, is ENGLISH BOB. English Bob has beady blue eyes, is about thirty-five and pulls constantly on a good cigar.

(in a rich English accent) No, sir, I believe the would-be murderer is a gentleman of French ancestry... or so it would seem. I hope I won't give offense if I observe that the French are known to be a race of assassins, though they can't shoot worth a damn...any Frenchman among the present company excluded of course. Crocker, not liking or understanding the interruption, gi English Bob a hard stare.
(to Crocker) Says here a fellow by the name of "Gitto." "G-U-I--T..."

(eyes on Bob) Sounds like a damn John Bull to me. "Gitto." THIRSTY, a cowboy sitting behind Crocker, turns in his se sensing the tension in the air and WW feels it too and sh uneasily... but English Bob is unperturbed and he puffs cheerfully on his cigar.  30.

Well, sirs... again not wishing to give offense... it might be a good idea if the country were to choose a Queen... or even a King ...rather than a president. One isn't as quick to take a shot at a King or a Queen. The majesty of royalty, you see...

(provocative) Maybe you don't wish to give offense, sir, but you are givin' it pretty thick. This country don't need no queens whatsoever, I guess. Crocker is shifting in his seat so that the revolver in h holster is prominent and there is uneasy stirring among t nearby passengers. A DRUMMER looks around for exits.
As a matter of fact, what I heard about Queens...
Shut up, Joe.
(to Thurston) Huh? What's got up your ass, Thirsty? This dude asshole...

(to Crocker, but his eyes on Bob) Might be the "dude" is English Bob ...the one who works for the Union Pacific shootin' Chinamen. Might be he wants for some dumb cowboy to touch his pistol... so's he can shoot him down. English Bob, unperturbed, just pulls on his cigar.
(sobered) That a fact, mister? You English Bob?
(affably) Why don't we shoot some turkeys, friend? Ten shots... a dollar a turkey. I'll shoot for the Queen, and you can shoot for... whomever.  31.
Turkeys bursting from long Nebrasks grass as the train wh screams. BLAM! A turkey plummets to earth. BLAM! Another goes down.
On the swaying platform between cars, his pistol smoking BOB brings it up again fast and sights and BLAM! AN EXPLOSION OF FEATHERS plummeting down and disappearing the long grass.

head_text.subj: VIEW ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE PLATFORM

text: Where WW Beauchamp, Crocker, Thurston, Fuzzy and the nerv Drummer, in a cheap bowler, are standing. They are all impressed with the fact that English Bob is one hell of a shot with a pistol.
(to Crocker) I believe that's eight for me... to one for you. A matter of seven of your American dollars.
(grudgingly counting silver dollars) Pretty damn good shootin'.... (daring) for a John Bull.
(accepting the money cheerfully) No doubt your aim was affected by your grief over the injury to your uh... president.
Bawling cattle milling in the pens south of Big Whiskey, the train hissing and steaming at a standstill.

Two leather valises and a leather rifle case as MUDDY CHANDLER tosses them on his mud wagon, a sort of open stagecoach. The scene is one of chaos as the train steams and hisses and baggage is tossed off and more is tossed on.  32.

It's a nickel up to Big Whiskey, gentlemen. Ww hands Chandler the money and, as he and English Bob cl into the mud wagon, they are accosted by GERMANY JOE SCHU who runs the livery stable and does horse business with railway passengers on the side.
I godd nize horzes I zell you, boyce. Nize prizes for Independence Day, boyce.
English Bob and W riding in the mud wagon, bouncing uncomfortably in spite of the slow pace, and eating dust sweating profusely.
(irritably) It's the climate does it. That and the infernal distances.
Does what?

Induces people to shoot persons in high places. (mopping his brow with his handkerchief) It's a savage country. That's the second one shot in twenty years. It's uncivilized shooting people of substance. The mud wagon rattles past the South Road sign. It is sim to the one of the North Road and says:

head_text.subj: NO FIREARMS IN BIG WHISKEY. ORDINANCE 14. DEPOSIT PISTOLS

text: Deputy ANDY RUSSELL stepping out of the County Office as mud wagon clatters to a stop in front of the Big Whisky I Andy is just twenty, a good looking kid with a badge on h vest and a holstered pistol. He watches the passengers cl out of the mud wagon and, as English Bob alights, his fro coat parts and gives ANDY just the quickest glimpse of a holstered pistol under the coat.  33.

Pardon me, gentlemen, but local ordinance obliges you to surrender your sidearms to proper authority for the duration of your visit. ww looks at English Bob and English Bob turns and looks A up and down very coolly.

Proper authority eh? (breezily) Well, sir... neither my companion nor I carry firearms on our persons. Rather, we trust in the goodwill of our fellow man and the forbearance of reptiles. And English Bob gives a smart bow, turns with a swirl of coat-tails that allows a brief glimpse of not one, but tw holstered pistols, and marches off. As WW follows English Bob, he glances nervously back to see what young Andy wil do but Andy just stares nonplussed. In that quick glimpse Andy saw how the weapons were tied down with thongs, mean the owner wanted a quick pull... and this shit is out of league.
KER-CHICK, CLACK, A HENRY RIFLE COCKED and the action che Andy is cleaning the weapon in the County Office.
Unarmed, my ass. SHUCK, KA-CHAK. CHARLEY HECKER breaks open a single barre shotgun and moves a shell in.
(wiping his brow nervously) Christ, it's hot.

((cheerfully) If I'm gonna get shot, I druther it was hot then cold. Everythin' hurts more in the cold. Fatty is sitting in a chair in front of the empty jail ce cleaning a revolver, oblivious to the tension.
You know how if you hit your thumb in the cold, how it...?  34.
Shut up, Fatty.
I only said... Outside a horse clatters up fast and Andy jumps nervously the window.
Clyde's back.
Little Bill with him?
No.
(worried) Shit. Clyde bursts in the door. He is wearing two gun-belts crossed, with a holster on each side. Since he has only o arm, he carries one pistol butt forward and the other but back.
You boys clean my Remington?
(holding it up) Cleaned an' loaded.
Where's Little Bill for Christ sake?
(inspecting the pistol) Ha. He was building his fucking porch.
Building his porch!
If you was to get shot, Andy, would you like it better to be a hot day or...?
(sharply) I ain't gonna get shot.
(to Clyde) He's coming ain't he?  35.
(ejecting shells) "Course he's coming.
Hey, I just loaded her. Watcha doin?
I don't trust nobody to load my guns, not for a shootin'.
What'd he say?
Little Bill? He didn't say nothing. Like I said, he was buildin' his porch. Have you seen that thing?
(sulking) It was all loaded. Jesus, Clyde, you got three pistols an' only one arm for Christ sake.

(to Fatty) I just don't wanna get killed for lack of shootin' back. (to Charley) You know there ain't a straight angle in that whole goddamn porch... or in the whole house for that matter. He's the worst fucking carpenter.
(worried) He didn't say nothin', huh?
(putting the 3rd pistol in his belt) Asked what they looked like, that's all. Christ, maybe he's tough but he sure ain't no carpenter.
Maybe he ain't so tough. Clyde looks up, surprised. There is a sudden silence.
(blurting it) He seem like... like he was... scared?  36.
(amazed) Little Bill? Him scared?
We never seen him up against any... like these ones... killers.
(looking at the frightened faces of Charley and Andy) Little Bill come out of Kansas an' Texas, boys. He worked them tough towns.
(ashamed) Just wondered. Anybody could be scared. Andy drops his eyes and looks away from Clyde.
(with meaning) No. He wasn't scared, boys. He just ain't a good carpenter.
English Bob, delighting in the smooth feel of his freshly shaved pink cheeks, climbs cheerfully out of the barber c still chattering at the poor BARBER.

...can see that there's a dignity in royalty... a majesty... that precludes the likelihood of assassination. The Barber is applying his little whisk broom to Bob's waistcoat while WW pulls out his purse to make payment.
Why, if you were to point a pistol at a King or a Queen, sir, I can assure you your hand would shake as though palsied...
(looking at Bob's pistols) I wouldn't point no pistol at nobody, sir.  37.

(putting on his frock coat over his guns) A wise policy. But if you did, I can assure you, the sight of royalty would cause you to dismiss all thoughts of bloodshed and stand... in awe. (pause) Whereas, a president... I mean, why not shoot a president? The Barber doesn't know how to take this guy, and just og him.
Now this Strawberry Alice person, tell me again.
Down the street and across. Greely's Beer Garden and Billiard parlor. Just ask for Alice and say you want a game of billiards.
(about to exit) Billiards, eh? Even though I don't really wish to play?
Don't matter. They burned the table in '78 for firewood.
Ah, I see. Ww has already stepped out and English Bob follows him ou the door.
English Bob steps out the door.
Come on, W. Let's... Something's wrong! There is a funny quiet and WW is froze like a ramrod. English Bob looks around.
Ten yards to Bob's right, pointing a 12 gauge shotgun and Fatty Rossiter a few feet away pointing his old Enfield.  38.
On Bob's left, pale and tense, pointing his Henry, and Cl Ledbetter kneeling near him, leveling one of his pistols.
Standing ten yards away in the empty dusty street where t Fourth of July flags are flapping.
Hullo, Bob. Boys, this here is English Bob.
(under his breath) Shit and fried eggs.
Been a long time, Bob. You run out of Chinamen?
(recovering his composure) Little Bill, I thought you were dead. I see you shaved off your chin whiskers.
(feeling his chin) Well, I was always tasting the soup two hours after I et it.
Empty, silent.
Of the Blue Bottle restaurant. EGGS ANDERSON, TOM LUCKINB MRS. PEEVEY, HOPPITY THOMAS, peering out.

head_text.subj: VIEW ALICE, KATE AND LITTLE SUE IN GREELY'S WINDOW

text: And, in the open doorway, ready to duck for cover, Skinny and Germany Joe Schultz and PADDY MCGEE, the cooper.
What I heard was that you fell off your horse drunk and broke your neck.
I heard that one myself, Bob. (MORE )
Hell, I even thought I was dead til I found out it was just I was in Nebraska. (pause) Who's your friend?
WwW Beauchamp... Little Bill Daggett and... "friends."
(nervous) From N-n-newton?... and H-hays and A- a-abilene?
(dryly) The same. Charley is taking all this in wide-eyed.
You work for the railroads too, Mister Beauchamp?
(scared to death) N-no. I wr-wr-wr-write... I wr-wr- write...
Letters?
Books. He's my biographer.
(fighting amazement) And WW is reaching for a pocket.
Andy and Charley and Clyde and Fatty tensing to fire.
I wouldn't do it, WwW. Ww freezes, terrified... and a puddle of urine forms at h feet.  40.
It's only a b-b-b-book...

(his pistol half-drawn) A book, huh? (returning his pistol and glancing at the piss) I guess that means you can read...An' I guess you boys seen them signs about surrendering your firearms... But then, like you told old Andy there, you ain't armed, are you, Bob?
Not really... (shrugging) Maybe a couple of Peacemakers... (bargaining) I imagine you could overlook those, eh, Bill? If you didn't see them... or hear them?

(cold as ice) I guess not, Bob. I don't like guns around. With a sardonic glance at the arsenal trained on him Engl Bob gives a shrug and holds open his coat in surrender, exposing two fancy holstered pistols. Little Bill gives Andy a head signal and Andy steps forwa and takes the pistols from English Bob's holsters.
Charley, see what kind of "books" Mister Beauchamp is packing... but watch you don't get we
(to Andy) Be careful with those, sonny. Onlookers are stepping out of doorways now and moving tim into the street forming a large semi-circle. The whores a among them.

No shit, Little Bill, all he's got is this here book. Charley holds up a dime novel with a lurid cover showing gentleman in a top hat protecting a woman with his body w  41. firing two pistols at seven disheveled looking "Western types." The title is "The Duke of Death."
(reading with effort) The... Duck of Death.
D-d-d-duke. The D-d-duke of Death. English Bob starts to go but Little Bill puts a hand on h shoulder.
Give me the .32, Bob. Furious, English Bob turns and looks into Bill's eyes and then, seeing no alternative, opens his vest esposing a sm pistol.
You leave me at the mercy of my enemies.

(taking the pistol) Enemies, Bob? You been talking about the Queen again? On Independence Day? A lot of the tension has gone out of the occasion and the crowd is beginning to murmur and people are starting to m and a couple of kids are running when suddenly... CRUNCH! English Bob's face seems to cave in with the forc of Little Bill's fist and Bob literally flies backward an slams into the side of the barber shop.
Alice gasping... Andy's jaw drops... Little Sue's eyes bulge... Charley gulps.
Slumped against the wall, blood pouring from his unhinged jaw, amazed.
Wh... what... ? Little Bill walks calmly up to him and WHAM... kicks him hard in the chest.  42.
Having a hard time swallowing and Mrs. Peevey turning awa and Eggs horrified and Alice's scared face.

Bloody, on all fours, pulling a knife from his waistcoat. but the whole effort is painful and hopeless. He hasn't a chance. Little Bill looks down at him for a moment from his enorm height, watching the smaller man's pitiful effort, then SLAM!... Little Bill kicks him in the ribs hard and you c hear air going out of Bob, and Bill steps hard on Bob's k hand and the bones crunch loudly.
Ww, white as a ghost and Andy is trying not to vomit. The is the sound of another brutal blow.
English Bob on all fours in the dusty street now, barely conscious. KA-WHUMP! Little Bill kicks him again, not angrily, but h

I guess you think I'm kickin' you, Bob... but it ain't so. (WHAM, another kick) What I'm doin' is talkin', hear? I'm talkin' to all them villains down in Kansas an' them villains in Cheyenne... (WHUMP )
Lettin' em know there ain't no whores' gold... Little Bill turns and looks hard at the whores and Alice sick from the violence and Little Sue is biting her lip a Silky has tears in her eyes.

(turning back to Bob and kicking him) ...an' how if there was... how they wouldn't want to come lookin' for it anyhow. Little Bill looks down with eyes as cold as ice and Engli Bob grovels in the bloody dust, barely conscious.  43.

Open country under a hot sun and Munny and Ned riding the horses at a walk and the saddles creaking and birds chirp in the five foot high grass. It is late morning in Northe Kansas and they have been riding since dawn, mostly in silence, but Ned has something on his mind and he glances Munny and frowns and then finally he blurts his question.
Say, Bill... You ever... ever go into town... an' all?
(surprised at the question) Sure, I got to. Got to get supplies.

No. I mean... (embarrassed) ...an' get yourself a woman? You know? Munny looks away quickly, embarrassed, and it seems like isn't going to answer and then, when he finally does, he keeps his eyes on the horizon.

Naw. Naw, I don't ever go into town for that. (pause) A man like me... A man like me can't get no woman but one he's gonna pay for... an' that ain't right... buyin' flesh. (looking at Ned) Claudia, God rest her soul, she wouldn't have wanted me doin' nothin' like that, me bein' a father, an' all. (he looks away again)
(rhetorically) Whaddaya do, just use your hand?

(after a nervous glance at Ned) Sometimes... yeah. (looking at the horizon) I don't miss it all that much. Ned is shaking his head, wondering at the transformation his old friend when...  44. CRACK! A RIFLE SHOT and the Albino mare rears violently, whinnying and hurling Munny out of the saddle and... Ned's roan bolts at full speed, Ned barely staying aboard CRACK! another shot.

On all fours in the tall grass. He feels his forehead and wipes away a little blood, and shakes his head to clear it. Then he hears rustling in the long grass and he whirls an pulls the Starr out of his belt and sitting back he aims where he heard the noise and he pulls back the hammer wit loud click.
(a whisper) Billy. Billy.
(lowering the pistol, relieved) Yeah. Ned crawls out of the grass next to Munny.
Some fucker's shootin' at us.
Yeah.
(alarmed, seeing blood) He hit you?

Naw. I bumped my head fallin' off of my horse. CRACK, another shot. Ned looks puzzled and he lifts his head up and tries to look around without exposing himself A hundred yards away Ned can see a clump of four or five trees and there is a little cloud of black smoke still ha in the air there and then a sudden flash of fire, smoke a
Ned doesn't even duck, he just frowns.
He ain't shootin' our way no more. (MORE )
(indicating the left) He's shootin' over that way. Who's he shootin' at over that way?
Beats the hell out of me.
You suppose maybe we're in somebody's field?
I didn't see nothin' planted. CRACK. Another shot. Ned ducks urgently.
Fuck, he's shootin' at us again. CRACK, CRACK, CRACK.
Jesus, he's shootin' up the whole fucking horizon. Munny is thinkinh about it, has an idea, weighs it and gi it atry.
(shouting) HEY.
You're marking us, Bill.
(ignoring him) HEY, KID.
Kid? The Kid's shootin at us?
Why would the Kid shoot at us?

head_text.subj: HEY KID, IT'S ME, BILL MUNNY.

text: The Kid rifle at his cheek is crouched behind one of the trees. His horse is standing nearby.  46.
Hey, Kid, is that you? It's me, Bill Munny. The Kid is frowning and finally he makes up his mind.
(shouting) YEAH. IT'S ME.
Don't shoot at us no more, okay? The Kid is peering around the tree and squinting ferociou
The field. It is one big blur. He can't see worth a shit. The Kid squinting and peering and worrying.
Ned Logan. My old partner, Ned Logan. Don't you shoot no more, okay? The Kid doesn't like it, he's nervous and twitching, tryi desperately to see what's going on out there.
We're gonna collect our horses an' come on over. You ain't gonna shoot no more, are you?
Bedraggled and sweaty, walking into the clump of trees leading his horse and Ned, behind him, leading his roan and looking just as bad.
Had to chase the damn horse a mile. The Kid is sitting under the shade tree looking sullen.
(angry) ; What was you shootin' at us for, anyhow?  47.
Thought you was followin' me.
Well, we was. Like you said, I changed my mind an'...
Wasn't nothin' said about no partner.
Well, this here's Ned Logan...Ned, this here's the Schofield Kid, nephew of Pete Sothow an’...
I seen two fellas followin' me, I guessed they come to kill me. (pause) We didn't talk about no other fella.
(squatting in front of The Kid, talking in a persuasive tone) Well, now Kid, there's two of these cowboys, ain't that so? Better there's three of us... maybe them cowboys got friends. Maybe...
I was gonna kill them two by myself. It don't take three. Ned walks over to where The Kid's rifle is leaning agains the tree and The Kid is watching nervously.
Now Ned's a hell of a shot with a rifle. Hell, he can hit a bird in the eye flyin'.
(picking up The Kid's rifle) Better'n you anyhow, Kid. You wasn't comin' close.
Keep your damn hands offa that rifle, Mister. The Kid is touching his pistol and Ned puts the rifle dow annoyed.  48.
I was only checkin' it for you. Thought maybe somethin' was bent.
Nothin's bent.
Well, you was shootin' every which way an'...
(to Munny) You gonna share your half with him?
Three ways, I figured.
No.
(to Ned) Sorry, Ned. Guess I wasted your time. See ya, Kid! Munny turns to go and Ned gives The Kid a disgusted look turns away.
(to Munny) You're goin' back with him?

(turning) He's my partner. He don't go, I don't. Ned is mounted and Munny starts to mount too, but the mar is as reluctant as ever, shying and prancing while MUNNY hops awkwardly with one foot in the stirrup.
What's it come to, three ways? Munny turns and looks at The Kid.
The three of them riding across open country. The Kid loo like he still has a thorn up his ass and the only sound i the creaking of saddles. Storm clouds are gathering behind them on the horizon.
Oh shit.  49. And The Kid looks back but of course he can't figure out what it is they saw.
What the hell are you pissin' about, I'd like to know?
(astonished) Huh?
Well, what were you lookin' at anyhow?
Lookin' at?
Clouds, Kid. We was lookin' at them clouds on account of we got a storm ridin' up our ass.
(looking back) Oh, them. (petulantly) Hell, I seen them. Ned frowns and looks at The Kid and something is botherin Ned.
A dry stream bed and the three men are riding single file now with The Kid in the lead but Ned has been thinking an trotting with his horse, he pulls alongside The Kid.
You was right to change your mind, Kid.
(surly, suspicious) Yeah?

(proudly) I'm a damn good shot. (looking up) See that hawk up there? I could kill that hawk with one shot. VIEW on the empty sky. There isn't any hawk. VIEW on Munny who is right beside them is looking up and doesn't see any hawk and he looks at Ned like he thought was crazy and he frowns.  50. The Kid just looks up and squints and looks ahead at the trail and keeps riding.
Hell, I could hit it too if I didn't mind wasting a shot. And Munny looks up again, amazed, because they must be cr both of them. And Ned reins his horse hard.
There ain't no hawk up there, Kid. And the Kid reins and turns and he locks eyes with Ned. H knows he's been found out.
Can't see worth a shit, can you? The Kid is furious, his eyes flick around and he spots something and he pulls out the Schofield.
See them fucking turtles?
Making their way up the stream bed ten yards away.
His Schofield spitting fire and smoke BLAM, BLAM.
BLAM, the third turtle exploding and following the other to oblivion.
(impressed) Shit.
(impressed but holding back) How far kin you see?
Far enough.
We ain't goin' to Nebraska on no turtle hunt. A hundred yards?  51.
More.
(testing) See that scrub oak yonder?
(furious) Fuck you.
(to Munny) He's blind, for Chri...
(pointing his pistol at Ned) I ain't blind, you asshole.
Now hold on, boys, hold on. Now, Kid, you kin see fifty yards, can't you?
Bet your ass I kin see fifty yards an' I kin shoot this sonofabitch...
Easy, Kid, easy. (looking Ned in the eye) Now, you hear that, Ned? The Kid can see fifty yards fine, hear?
(under his breath) Jesus.
Fifty yards ain't bad. (glancing at the horizon) Guess we better get along.
STORM CLOUDS building behind them on the horizon.
The lurid cover, "The Duke of Death" by W. W. Beauchamp.  52. Little Bill is looking at the cover, his feet propped on desk in the county office. It is night and the office is lit with an oil lamp.
